I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  Turkmenistan has experienced fast development over the last few decades, achieving 
upper-middle income status as of 2012.1 However, the country is facing an economic slowdown 
as result of low oil prices and decline in trade with significant impact on poverty and social 
development.2 This is aggravated by the recent coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic 
causing further economic hardships.3 The Asian Development Bank (ADB) estimates that gross 
domestic product (GDP) growth will fall to 2.3% in 2020 compared to 6.3% in 2019.4 Turkmenistan 
has committed to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), including achieving good health 
and well-being for all, but faces serious capacity and institutional challenges in its health system. 
 
2.  In 2019, ADB conducted a health sector assessment in Turkmenistan and found the most 
pressing challenge is the low quality of health services.  Access to high quality health care is 
limited, even though the government has made significant investments in health infrastructure. 
Facilities in rural regions are poorly equipped and understaffed, and the country relies heavily on 
secondary and tertiary care. In response to these health concerns and an increasing burden of 
non-communicable diseases  the government has initiated the State Health Program (SHP), a 
multi-sectoral plan that aims to improve the health of the population through provision of high 
quality and affordable services, sustainability of health financing, and reform of the health system 
based  on  the  latest  medical  science.      The  central  pillars  for  the  SHP  are  upgrading  of 
infrastructure, prevention and control of communicable diseases, awareness raising for disease 
prevention, expanding health insurance, and upgrading human resources for health (HRH).  
 
3.  Insufficient HRH poses a critical bottleneck in the implementation of the SHP. Shortages 
of qualified staff make it difficult to implement government plans and respond to the increasing 
demand for higher quality health services. Although international standards and protocols have 
been adopted, health workers lack understanding of basic medical principles and have little 
exposure  to  in-service  training  and  latest  evidence-based  practices  and  literature.    The 
government has attempted to improve HRH in the last decade, but most reforms have focused 
only on physicians, such as upgrading the State Medical University in 2010 and establishment of 
post-graduate  professional  development  faculty  for  physicians.  Nurses  have  received  less 
investment, despite being the first point of contact in primary health care (PHC), and primarily 
responsible  for  patient  monitoring,  coordination  of  care,  patient  discharge,  and  infection 
prevention control in health facilities. There is abundant literature linking higher nurse staffing 
levels to lower risks of mortality, shorter hospital stays and fewer occurrences of other adverse 
patient events,  but the country has not prioritized upgrading  the quantity and quality of nurses 
and other paramedical staff. While the country has not reported any cases of COVID-19 at the 
time of writing, nurses are expected to play a critical role in patient triage, case detection, and 
patient management in intensive care units should cases appear in the country.  
 
4.  In 2019, the government approved the National Action Plan (NAP) for the Development of 
Human Resources for the Health in Turkmenistan prepared by the Ministry of Health and Medical 
Industry (MOHMI). The NAP covers the five strategic areas of HRH planning and deployment, 
education and training, personnel management and working conditions, monitoring, and research. 
The  NAP  complements  the  SHP  and  its  emphasis  on  the  importance  of  developing  a 
comprehensive nursing workforce to strengthen maternal and child health services and primary

health care (PHC). The NAP also supports the SHP’s objectives of increasing nurse staffing levels 
and bolstering the role of family nurses by expanding their job descriptions and upgrading their 
training. In response to the lack of nurses and the need to support the implementation of the NAP 
and SHP, the MOHMI seeks ADB’s support to upgrade the Ashgabat Medical School, and 
strengthen HRH, management, and monitoring and research. 
 
5.  The project is expected to be financed with a $75 million loan from ADB’s ordinary capital 
resources.  Co-financing  and  private  sector  opportunities  will  be  explored  during  project 
preparation.  
 
6.  The proposed project will be aligned with the following impact: to provide effective health 
care focused on the needs of the population and ensuring equitable access to health services, 
which is aligned with the National Action Plan for the Development of Human Resources for 
Health in Turkmenistan for 2019–2025. The project will have three outputs: (i) modern nursing 
education institution established; (ii) quality of nursing education and training improved; and (iii) 
management of human resources for health strengthened. The outcome of the project is to 
improve the quality and supply of the nurses. 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
7.  The transaction technical assistance (TRTA) will help the government prepare the project. 
The TRTA is justified given the specialized nature of skills required in areas such as modernizing 
the Ashgabat Medical School, review of the medical education curricula and nursing program, 
and development of reforms to sector governance and management.5 This would be ADB’s first 
project in the health sector in Turkmenistan, and the TRTA will help the government to (i) review 
the technical, economic and financial viability of the project and ascertain the project rationale, 
scope, cost, schedule, implementation arrangements, risks and mitigation measures; (ii) ensure 
compliance with ADB’s safeguard policy statement (2009) and identify mitigation measures and 
institutional strengthening; (iii) assist the project executing agency and implementing agency 
undertake advance actions for the ensuing project; and (iv) develop a strategy for engagement 
with ADB in the health sector reform.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Project design developed and partnership strategy prepared. This output 
will develop the technical design parameters including (i) the preparation of technical assessment 
of nursing and/or medical education system and program, assessment of quality, supply and skills 
training of nurses, identify public-private partnership programs; and review of medical education 
curricula; (ii) preparation of detailed project costings for the three outputs, including civil works, 
consulting  services,  goods,  equipment,  capacity  building,  and  project  implementation;  (iii) 
identification of capacity-building and professional development requirements (for faculty and 
students) including licensing and registration; (iv) preparation of the design and monitoring 
framework, including specification of performance indicators and project activities; (v) preparation 
of initial architectural designs for Ashgabat Medical School to be upgraded to a modern medical 
college; and (vi) development of strategic document for ADB’s engagement in the health sector 
reform.  
 
5  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 4 November 2020.

3 
 
9.  Output 2: Due diligence undertaken. This output will support the project’s due diligence, 
including the (i) environmental and social safeguards assessment; (ii) economic and financial 
analyses; (iii) gender, poverty, and social analyses; (iv) procurement capacity and financial 
management assessments of the executing agencies; (v) procurement risk assessment and 
strategic procurement planning; (vi) risk assessment and management plan. The output will 
undertake  a  detailed  assessment  and  screening  to  confirm  the  level  of  risks,  identify  the 
institutional capacity requirements and prepare an action plan as measures to identify the 
constraints and deficiencies. 
 
10.  Output 3: Project processing and start-up facilitated. This output will include assisting 
in the preparation of (i) project and all linked documents; (ii) list and specification of equipment; 
(iii) terms of reference of all project implementation consultants, project implementation unit (PIU) 
support staff, and other individual consultants; (iii) project start-up and implementation support, 
including assisting the executing agency in the establishment of PIU office, recruitment of PIU 
staff, draft bid documents and request for proposals. The output will help the project achieve 
readiness through completion of advance actions to ensure smooth project implementation.  
 
11.  Output 4: Support for the establishment of personnel management information 
system. This output will support the review of existing systems and processes for managing 
human resources for health, and development of the initial design for the human resources for 
health registry. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $0.75 million, of which $0.70 million will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-Others). The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of 
exemptions on taxes and duties, counterpart staff, office accommodations and other in-kind 
contributions. The government was informed that approval of the TRTA does not commit ADB to 
finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TRTA. The Ministry of Health and Medical Industry (MOHMI) will 
be the executing agency. The Social Sector Division of the Central and West Asia Department 
will advertise, select, supervise and evaluate the consultants and will coordinate the project 
preparation with the MOHMI and other development partners. The TRTA will be implemented 
from December 2020 to December 2023 to ensure effective project preparation and start-up. The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.

14.  Consulting services. ADB will recruit a consulting firm to implement the TRTA. About 43 
person-months of consulting services are required, of which 25 person-months are international 
and 18 person-months are national. A consulting firm will be engaged using the quality- and 
cost-based selection (QCBS) method with a standard quality––cost ratio of 90:10 using full 
technical proposals (FTP).6 ADB may also recruit additional short-term consultants and resource 
persons to provide technical expertise and capacity building support for the ensuing project, 
assessments,  and  policy  dialogue,  as  needed,  using  individual  consultant  recruitment 
procedures in specialized areas  such  as  procurement,  health,  financial  management,  and 
education.  ADB  will  engage consultants  and  procure  goods  and  office  equipment  for 
consultants’  use  during  TRTA implementation  following  the  ADB  Procurement  Policy  - 
Goods, Works, Non-consulting and Consulting Services (2017, as amended from time to time)
